title: What to expect in the 3Q GDP report
text:
U.S. economic growth is expected to have decelerated in the third quarter as weaker business investment and moderating consumer spending weighed on the pace of expansion.

The Bureau of Economic Analysis releases its first print on third-quarter gross domestic product at 8:30 a.m. ET Wednesday. Here are the main measures expected from the report, based on Bloomberg-compiled consensus data:

3Q GDP Annualized quarter-on-quarter: +1.6%, vs. +2.0% in Q2

3Q Personal Consumption: +2.6% vs. +4.6% in Q2

3Q Core Personal Consumption Expenditures quarter-on-quarter: +2.2%, vs. +1.9% in Q2

The Atlanta Federal Reserve’s closely watched GDPNow model pointed to a slightly less pronounced deceleration to 1.7% growth in the third quarter, based on the institution’s most recent prediction on Monday.

“Incoming data point to a moderating pace of GDP growth in the second half of the year,” Sam Bullard, managing director and senior economist for Wells Fargo Securities, wrote in a note Tuesday. “As the tailwinds from fiscal stimulus wane, trade policy uncertainty persists, and sluggish global demand continues, the pace of U.S. GDP growth should moderate over the coming quarters.”

A slowdown in nonresidential investment likely generated a drag on headline GDP for the July through September period. Business investment turned negative during the second quarter for the first time since 2016, with most economists expecting these declines to have continued into the third quarter. Ongoing geopolitical concerns have spurred business to shore up resources and curb new spending to prepare for a future downturn.

This trend has been reflected in the bulk of the latest economic data releases, with many of these serving as leading indicators for the eventual GDP print. September’s manufacturing activity index report from the Institute for Supply Management showed a contraction in new orders, production and employment, and fell to the lowest level in a decade.

“The near-term outlook for capital spending remains weak, reflecting slowing global growth, deteriorating business confidence and a softening pace of manufacturing activity,” Bullard said.

Some transitory manufacturing factors, including fewer shipments of Boeing (BA) aircraft and the 40-day United Auto Workers strike on General Motors (GM), may also drag on headline GDP, other economists pointed out.

People walk along a main shopping street in Manhattan in New York City. (Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images) More

Activity in the U.S. service sector – the larger share of the overall economy – had been more resilient earlier this year by comparison. Personal consumption rose by 4.6%, the most in four-and-a-half years, in the second quarter.

However, cracks have since begun to show in service-related industries as well, leading economists to temper expectations that a strong consumer will prop up flagging growth in other areas for this GDP report. The ISM’s report on service sector activity fell to a three-year low in September.

“Until recently, the domestic data flow in the U.S. has been split, with weakness in manufacturing and trade-related sectors offset by solid growth in household spending,” Barclays economist Michael Gapen said in a note last week. “The recent data flow in the U.S. suggests that softness in the goods-producing sectors is leading to a broader-based slowing in economic activity.”

Notably, September and August’s jobs reports reflected fewer-than-expected job gains, and wage increases slowed. Retail sales for both months also missed expectations, pointing to slower household spending. These are expected to pull down the personal consumption component of GDP, a segment comprising nearly 70% of economic activity.

Other areas of the economy, however, have remained strong or improved in the three months to September. Economists expect that government outlays likely remained robust in the third quarter, following a 4.8% increase in the second quarter. And the Commerce Department’s recent housing reports have shown a rebound in single-family homebuilding, presaging a stronger residential construction contribution in Wednesday’s GDP report.
description: U.S. economic growth is expected to have decelerated in the third quarter as weaker business investment and moderating consumer spending weigh on the pace of expansion.
